<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MAP5105</span> - Trauma skills<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">24 points, SCA Band 2, 0.500 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MAP5105">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Cameron">Professor Peter Cameron</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Cameron">Professor Peter Cameron</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MAP5105&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MAP5105">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-alfred-hospital.html">Alfred Hospital</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>This unit is offered annually via the Alfred. Please contact the School of Rural Health directly for more information.</p>
<p>Email: <a href="mailto:advancedhealthcarepractice@monash.edu">advancedhealthcarepractice@monash.edu</a></p>
<p>Telephone: +61 3 5128 1015</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit has been created in collaboration with the Alfred Emergency and Trauma Centre for students seeking credit from studies in Emergency and Trauma Evidence Based Medicine; Emergency and Trauma Research Methods; Emergency and Trauma Clinical Leadership and Management and Trauma Theory and Practice.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<p>Emergency and Trauma Evidence Based Medicine</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understand the benefits and limitations of evidence based medicine</li>
<li>Perform a comprehensive search of the medical literature</li>
<li>Describe quantitative techniques for data collection and basic analysis for reporting data</li>
<li>Critically appraise studies of therapy, harm, diagnosis and prognosis</li>
<li>Interpret information generated by systematic reviews

<p>Emergency and Trauma Research Methods</p></li>
<li>Create a research question amenable to rigorous scientific investigation</li>
<li>Design a research protocol</li>
<li>Justify the selection of the research methodology</li>
<li>Identify ethical issues related to the proposed study</li>
<li>Transform information gathered as part of the proposed study into usable data for scientific analysis

<p>Emergency and Trauma Clinical Leadership and Management</p></li>
<li>Implement a robust and defensible approach to clinical leadership in the emergency and trauma context;</li>
<li>Apply a critically reflective approach towards the management of human resources' issues in the emergency and trauma context;</li>
<li>Positively influence key stakeholders within the emergency and trauma context</li>
<li>Critically evaluate quality improvement measures in the emergency and trauma context</li>
<li>Apply high-level analytical and leadership skills in relation to the implementation of a range of health care projects of relevance to the emergency and trauma context ;

<p>Trauma Theory and Practice</p></li>
<li>Implement specialist medical diagnostic skills during the assessment and management of trauma patients</li>
<li>Apply specialist trauma medical knowledge and skills to the resuscitation of the critically injured  trauma patient</li>
<li>Critically apply an evidence-based approach towards the implementation of medical procedural and technical skills required in the trauma setting</li>
<li>Integrate trauma medical theory with practical experience across a range of patient cases and situations</li>
<li>Apply a critically reflective approach towards the management of trauma patients</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Emergency and Trauma Evidence Based Medicine</p>
<ul>
<li>Assignment 1 (1,000 words) (20%)</li>
<li>Assignment 2 (1,000 words) (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Online exercices - participation &amp; content 1,000 words (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Emergency and Trauma Research Methods</p>
<ul>
<li>Assignment 1 (1,000 words) (20%)</li>
<li>Assignment 2 (2,000 words &amp; 10 minute oral presentation) (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Online exercises participation &amp;  content (3000 words) (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Emergency and Trauma Clinical Leadership and Management</p>
<ul>
<li>12 weekly online discussion questions (1000 words) (40%)</li>
<li>Written report (4,000 words) (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Personal reflection (1000 words) (20%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Trauma Theory and Practice</p>
<ul>
<li>Online MCQ for each topic (1,000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>Workplace based case review report (3,000 words) (40% Hurdle)</li>
<li>Six mini-CEX assessments (3,000 words) (30%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>HURDLE REQUIREMENTS:</p>
<ul>
<li>Observership: attendance at minimum prescribed practicum hours with logbook evidence</li>
<li>Attendance at two day "Trauma Resuscitation Workshop"</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">APG5609</span> - Sustainable tourism development and planning<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 3, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-APG5609">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-languages-literatures-cultures-and-linguistics.html">School of Languages, Literatures, Cultures and Linguistics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<!-- TBA -->TBA
        
        
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<!-- TBA -->TBA
        
        
      
    <br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-APG5609">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>APG4709</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>The unit has a <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/currentstudents/field-trips/">domestic field trip</a><span class="hbk-print-url">domestic field trip (<a href="http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/currentstudents/field-trips/">http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/currentstudents/field-trips/</a>)</span> component and may incur an additional cost.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered in <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">non-standard teaching periods</a><span class="hbk-print-url">non-standard teaching periods (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Patterns of sustainable tourism product development and management and the contemporary role of planning for tourism. Key study areas comprise the future of global tourism, government policy and industry practice, the impacts of the tourism industry on the economy, communities and the environment and the design and implementation of tourism planning.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of the unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Encourage critical analysis of sustainable tourism development in terms of potential positive and negative impacts on cultures and the environment</li>
<li>Familiarise students with the historical origins of tourism so that they may apply their understanding to contemporary tourism patterns and dilemmas</li>
<li>Acquaint students with the planning and policy making role of Governments, private operators and communities in tourism development</li>
<li>Enable students to 'read' changes in tourism landscapes from which they can draw conclusions and raise questions about future tourism development</li>
<li>Familiarise students with planning procedures for tourism purposes</li>
<li>Develop students' research and presentation skills on tourism related subjects.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/international-development-practice">International development practice</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/international-sustainable-tourism-management">International sustainable tourism management</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/tourism">Tourism</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MCE5105</span> - Theory: ART laboratory processes (andrology)<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MCE5105">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-obstetrics-and-gynaecology.html">Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Temple-Smith">Peter Temple-Smith</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Sally Catt">Dr Sally Catt</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MCE5105&amp;tpCode=S1-32&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester (extended)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MCE5105&amp;tpCode=S2-32&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester (extended)</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MCE5105">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-monash-medical-centre.html">Monash Medical Centre</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester (extended) 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>First semester (extended) 2019 (Online)</li><li>Second semester (extended) 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in M6010</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will focus on diagnostic and therapeutic andrology procedures and their utilisation in an ART setting. Students will learn about conventionally measured features of semen in order to determine the clinical thresholds distinguishing fertile, sub-fertile and infertile patients.</p>
<p>Currently marketed novel analysis and preparation techniques will be critically analysed for their clinical effectiveness. The theory behind sperm preparation for intrauterine insemination, conventional IVF and ICSI with both fresh and frozen sperm will be discussed.</p>
<p>Preparation of sperm from testicular and epididymal surgical extraction will be compared to ejaculate preparation. Students will have the opportunity to apply their knowledge on andrology to a clinical case study and make clinical assessments of human semen samples via an online platform.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Evaluate how a diagnostic semen analysis reflects clinical significance.</li>
<li>Critique the key components of conventional and novel sperm preparation and cryopreservation techniques.</li>
<li>Identify treatment strategies for male infertility patients based on andrology parameters.</li>
<li>Critique surgical sperm extraction and preparation techniques of testicular and epididymal samples.</li>
<li>Apply andrology concepts to determine diagnoses in clinical case studies.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Andrology case study (iSAP) (2000 words in total ) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Written andrology assignment (2000 words ) (35%)</li>
<li>Online quiz (25%)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>For on-campus students, this unit is conducted over four weeks in Semester 1. It is expected that students attended all lectures and tutorials associated with this unit.</p>
<p>For off-campus students, all material is accessible online during Semester 1.</p>
<p>Expect 18 hours per week of directed and self-directed learning over a four week block.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/reproductive-sciences">Reproductive sciences</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">GRS4201</span> - Comparative reproduction and conservation<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-GRS4201">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-obstetrics-and-gynaecology.html">Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Kiri Beilby">Dr Kiri Beilby</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Temple-Smith">Associate Professor Peter Temple-Smith</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=GRS4201&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-GRS4201">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-monash-medical-centre.html">Monash Medical Centre</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in one of the following course codes: 0101, M5010</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will focus on the reproductive biology and breeding of animals.  The lectures and tutorials will build on an understanding of basic reproductive physiology and endocrinology to explore ways in which reproduction can be manipulated to increase the reproductive efficiency and genetic gain in farm animals and animals in danger of becoming extinct.  How this information can be applied to the monitoring and regulation of reproduction in pets, zoo animals, Australian native animals and vertebrate pest species will also be explored.  The approaches that will be examined include hormonal and immunological manipulation of reproduction, artificial insemination (AI), in vitro fertilization (IVF), intra-cytoplasmic sperm. A facility that is using these approaches will allow students to see first hand how fundamental information can be applied to achieve environmental and/or commercial outcomes.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the techniques that are available to manipulate reproduction in animals</li>
<li>Apply the principles of reproductive technologies to the management of farm animals, endangered species, captive animals, Australian native animals and vertebrate pest species</li>
<li>Discuss the limitations of techniques available to manipulate reproduction in animals</li>
<li>Justify the use of various techniques for improving breeding and population genetics in animals</li>
<li>Identify and apply current research findings to achieve environmental and/or commercial gains in animal breeding systems</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Examination (2 hours) (45%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>PeerWise (5%)</li>
<li>Captive breeding scenario (3,000 words) (50%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will be held over six weeks in second semester. In addition to attendance at lectures and tutorials students are required to attend practical demonstrations and site visits. Attendance from 9 am to 5 pm for a 3 day laboratory project is also required.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/reproductive-sciences">Reproductive sciences</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="mailto:enquiries@med.monash.edu.au">enquiries@med.monash.edu.au</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">MEC6410</span> - Research practices<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">0 points, SCA Band 2, 0.000 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MEC6410">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-mechanical-and-aerospace-engineering.html">Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Davies">Professor Chris Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Prabhakar Ranganathan">Dr Prabhakar Ranganathan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MEC6410&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MEC6410">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>For students enrolled in a PhD in mechanical, aerospace or mechatronics only.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ERU0005.html">ERU0005</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ERU0013.html">ERU0013</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>MEC5410</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit addresses the scientific method in relation to engineering research including formal logic, how to formulate a hypothesis; experimental design and analysis; presentation of a scientific argument; the philosophy of research and the intellectual tradition. The unit will explore research in industry, and the commercialisation pathway.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the successful completion of this unit you will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse scientific communications to identify research questions, discern inductive arguments leading to hypotheses and deductive arguments leading to valid experimental tests.</li>
<li>Generate a research proposal by applying the hypothetico-deductive framework to a research problem.</li>
<li>Reflect on the prevalent sociological perspectives of science and their consequences for the economics, politics and management of scientific research.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 70%</p>
<p>Final Examination (2 hours): 30%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>The minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 120 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. The unit requires on average two or three hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher-directed learning, invited seminars, peer directed learning, online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/mechanical-engineering">Mechanical Engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">MDC5220</span> - Multimedia design studio 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MDC5220">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jeffrey Janet">Mr Jeffrey Janet</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jeffrey Janet">Mr Jeffrey Janet</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MDC5220&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MDC5220&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MDC5220">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MMD4001.html">MMD4001</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4120.html">MDC4120</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MMD5002.html">MMD5002</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit advances the student's knowledge gained in Multimedia Design Studio 1 (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MMD4001.html">MMD4001</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>) and places a strong emphasis on digital experience design. Particular importance is placed on the role of interface design, interactivity, virtual space and storytelling in multimedia design, including the skills and techniques to use these elements across a range of media platforms. Students undertake project work that explores a wide range of design processes, technical skills and conceptual models involved with the production of interactive media. Individual's specialist skills and folio preparation will also be covered.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Critically approach problem-solving, embracing current technological and philosophical developments in multimedia design;</li>
<li>Analyse digital media design, and identify the various multimedia elements and authoring techniques used;</li>
<li>Understand and have the ability to analyse the benefits and constraints of different media delivery platforms for multimedia design, including digital video, the internet, site-specific installation and other technologies;</li>
<li>Further develop creative and specialist studio skills specific to multimedia design;</li>
<li>Produce multimedia design prototypes by applying a range of design problem-solving methodologies, multimedia design and technical skills to respond to challenges;</li>
<li>Develop a self directed approach to the development of multimedia design works, utilising independent research and evaluation methods;</li>
<li>Understand the specialised roles identified in the multimedia design industry, and identify which role best matches their set of skills, and;</li>
<li>Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>24 hours per week including 8 contact hours plus 16 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">APG5553</span> - Field studies in sustainable development<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-APG5553">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-politics-and-international-relations.html">Politics and International Relations</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Eleanor Gordon">Dr Eleanor Gordon</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<!-- TBA -->tba
        
        
      
    <br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-APG5553">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>APG4553</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>This unit is an <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">international study program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">international study program (<a href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad">http://future.arts.monash.edu/learning-abroad</a>)</span> that requires an application to be enrolled and may incur additional cost.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered as part of the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">Summer Arts Program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Summer Arts Program (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html</a>)</span>.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered in <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">non-standard teaching periods</a><span class="hbk-print-url">non-standard teaching periods (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This field studies unit explores the concept of sustainable development in Asia and  draws attention to the practical constraints and issues associated with translating the Sustainable Development Goals into regional policy and practice. Working across multiple development sectors and with a range of local partners, the unit provides students with the opportunity to apply inter-disciplinary and cross-cultural problem solving skills outside the classroom, while contributing to a local organisation, as detailed in point 3 below.</p>
<p>The unit is divided into four phases. Students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Attend pre-departure preparatory workshops in Melbourne. Topics covered include understanding the Sustainable Development Goals and their implementation, an overview of sustainable development issues in the host country, and an overview of cross-cultural norms, safety and logistical information.</li>
<li>Participate in a week long journey across a specific region/area  in the host country where students will meet with a variety of groups to discuss sustainable development challenges. Themes include:  post-conflict transitions, livelihood development, sustainable resource management, gender empowerment, disaster management, migration; climate change, ecotourism; urbanisation, disabilities, and sustainability education.</li>
<li>In the host-country, work  in a small team to provide a service to a partner organisation addressing a specific organizational need over a two-week period. Examples of a service includes conducting a needs assessment, designing and writing monitoring and evaluation reports, event coordination, stakeholder research, conducting a gender analysis, designing training programs, writing project and grant proposals, or developing a communication and media strategy.</li>
<li>Attend a briefing workshop prior to leaving the country to share and reflect on their work.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students are expected to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify, describe, and interpret the concept of sustainable development in the context of development practice;</li>
<li>demonstrate advanced understanding of the complex constraints, issues and opportunities associated with translating the Sustainable Development Goals into practice;</li>
<li>critique and integrate theoretical knowledge and frameworks acquired through their studies to practical situations;</li>
<li>apply practical skills including working in interdisciplinary teams and cross-cultural skills;</li>
<li>reflect upon skills required to work in the area of sustainable development and identify skills they wish to develop further and;</li>
<li>effectively present complex ideas about sustainable development practice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Fieldwork in an overseas country </p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/environment-and-governance">Environment and governance</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/international-development-practice">International development practice</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGF1100">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-city-melbourne.html">City (Melbourne)</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Trimester A 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Trimester B 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Trimester C 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGW1100.html">MGW1100</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Communication theory emphasising written and oral communication in relation to organisational, intrapersonal, interpersonal and group communication. Importance of relationships in the work context, language, listening and nonverbal behaviour. Interpersonal contexts include negotiation, interviewing, feedback, coaching and counselling. Group communication -- roles, leadership and facilitation, problem-solving, decision making and group creativity.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>describe and discuss contemporary theories and concepts in interpersonal communication</li>
<li>examine the role of communication in management, particularly in leadership, decision making, conflict resolution, creativity and problem-solving</li>
<li>extend personal communication skills by identifying opportunities for growth and strategies for development</li>
<li>demonstrate competence and professionalism in structuring and delivering persuasive messages</li>
<li>critically analyse communication style.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BMS2062</span> - Introduction to bioinformatics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BMS2062">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biomedical-sciences.html">School of Biomedical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Elizabeth Davis">Assoc. Professor Elizabeth Davis</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Anna Roujeinikova">Associate Professor Anna Roujeinikova</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Terry Kwok">Dr Terry Kwok</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMS2062&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BMS2062">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in one of the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science (including double degree programs)</li>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science (Scholar Program)</li>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science Advanced with Honours</li>
</ul>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>MOL2022.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Bioinformatics unites the major advances in biology, biochemistry and the biomedical sciences with those in computing, bioinformatics and networking. The unit covers the application of the internet to biomedical sciences; organisation and uses of scientific databases; use of computational methods in genomics and proteomics; fundamentals of molecular modelling; analysis and presentation of biomedical data; and communication of biomedical data using information technology.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse DNA and RNA sequences and predict gene products</li>
<li>Identify conserved features in sequences and structures that define the function of macromolecules</li>
<li>Navigate databases to identify sequences and data on mutations associated with disease.</li>
<li>Construct and analyse sequence alignments, molecular phylogeny and molecular models of proteins and design strategies to assess gene function by reverse genetics.</li>
<li>Interpret structural and functional effects of mutations and predict/state molecular mechanisms underlying the resulting disease.</li>
<li>Investigate and communicate, verbally and through writing, the applications of bioinformatics to areas of biomedical science including the development of drugs and therapeutics</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>In-semester theory tests (13%)</li>
<li>Final exam (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Projects and assignments (47%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle requirements: a pass grade in the final exam must be obtained to pass the unit. A pass in the projects and assignments must also be obtained to pass the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>2 Lectures per week, 1 three hour practical session per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/biomedical-science">Biomedical science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">APG5355</span> - Journalism and technology<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-APG5355">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-journalism.html">Journalism</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Stephanie Brookes">Dr Stephanie Brookes</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nick Parkin">Mr Nick Parkin</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Stephanie Brookes">Dr Stephanie Brookes</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-APG5355">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The journalism and media industries are currently undergoing rapid and profound changes due to technological innovation. These changes are affecting and challenging traditional journalistic business models, editorial content, newsgathering methods and audience access. New technology is leading to innovative and exciting ways to tell journalistic stories and report the news. But it is also creating challenges, including the rise of non-traditional media players, privacy concerns, and complex ethical and legal issues.</p>
<p>This unit is divided into two distinct sections: a research component and a journalism practice component. The research component will examine the broader implications of technological change in journalism and the media, including looking at advanced technology, shifting media power, and the ethical/legal challenges resulting from rapid change. The journalism practice component will give students an opportunity to produce new and innovative works of journalism using technology, apps and social media.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>explain how shifts in technology are affecting local, national and international events relevant to current affairs, journalism, media and traditional power structures;</li>
<li>produce research work examining how technological changes are affecting and changing media industries;</li>
<li>gather and deliver real journalistic content using new technology, including mobile reporting, social media, interviewing, video, photography;</li>
<li>analyse the key ethical and legal issues and obligations associated with gathering and delivering content using new technology;</li>
<li>work independently and as part of a team to produce content to tight deadlines;</li>
<li>convey information in a clear, concise, factual and objective way using journalism and news conventions.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/journalism">Journalism</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">MDC5310</span> - Interaction design studio 3<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">18 points, SCA Band 1, 0.375 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MDC5310">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=In Dae Hwang">Dr In Dae Hwang</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=In Dae Hwang">Dr In Dae Hwang</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MDC5310&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MDC5310&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MDC5310">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4120.html">MDC4120</a></span>, or by permission</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4201.html">MDC4201</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4202.html">MDC4202</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4215.html">MDC4215</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC4216.html">MDC4216</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC5201.html">MDC5201</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MDC5215.html">MDC5215</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit aims to consolidate learning from previous studio units in the Interaction Design specialisation sequence and completes the technical, cognitive and creative skills required to design for industry. Students will be designing interactive artefacts, systems or services based on equivalent industry projects; or working on actual industry problems. They will be exposed to specific and relevant industry and/or social issues; and required to produce innovative solutions that weave together technology, place and product and user.</p>
<p>The unit encourages experimentation and skill development with tangible materials and interactive technology via data gathering, analysis, evaluation and design. Students will produce high quality designs that examine the extension of physical artefacts and tangible interfaces as elements of connectivity that help users to mediate between the real and digital worlds.</p>
<p>The project supports students in a broad range of interests, including the application of advanced technologies, electronics and programming, physical or virtual interface manipulation, and material and engineering fabrication.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Research and integrate comprehensive Tangible Interaction Design concepts, theories and design approaches to design interactive artefacts, systems or services;</li>
<li>Utilise contextual diagrams and interfaces as core components in a design outcome with consideration of the projects industrial or societal  context;</li>
<li>Apply research, communication and advanced technical skills to plan and manage comprehensive interaction design solutions from initial concept to final resolution;</li>
<li>Communicate ideas and concepts in order to critically justify designs through a process of observation, reflection, analysis, selection, interpretation and expression;</li>
<li>Critically analyse and evaluate the rationale for integrating interactive technologies in a design solution;</li>
<li>Observe and employ occupational health and safety appropriate to studio practice.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>24 hours per week including 8 contact hours plus 16 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3290</span> - Global leadership and advanced research program<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3290">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ernest Koh">Dr Ernest Koh</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ernest Koh">Dr Ernest Koh</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS3290&amp;tpCode=WS-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Winter semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3290">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Winter semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Winter semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>A minimum grade of a Distinction average.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2290.html">ATS2290</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>Students need to contact the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/contact-arts/">Arts Student Services</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Arts Student Services (<a href="http://future.arts.monash.edu/contact-arts/">http://future.arts.monash.edu/contact-arts/</a>)</span> desk to enrol in the unit.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered as part of the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/winter-program.html">Winter Arts Program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Winter Arts Program (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/winter-program.html">http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/winter-program.html</a>)</span>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The ICUR LARP (Leadership and Advanced Research Program) is a prestigious, externally-funded, invitation-only program aimed at high-achieving students interested in considering a career in research in both industry and academia. It is designed to provide an opportunity for talented undergraduates from all disciplines and areas across Monash University to work together in multidisciplinary research teams, encompassing not just their peers at Monash but also fellow undergraduates at other world class universities in Singapore, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.</p>
<p>Students acquire and hone highly sought-after skills in research and leadership; identify and develop research synergies across disciplines; learn to write up their research for different publication genres including refereed journals; develop competency and agility to work in a global, cross-cultural environment; and refine their ability to communicate complex research findings and ideas to intelligent multidisciplinary audiences. Students can also access exclusive international mobility funding schemes that are built into the unit to gain experience in writing applications for funding, and deepen transnational collaborative links and experiences within and between student teams.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>develop a high level of cross-cultural literacy in leading and managing a multidisciplinary research team that spans the globe;</li>
<li>develop the ability to initiate and lead multidisciplinary approaches to solving problems;</li>
<li>understand the commonalities and specificities of research imperatives at local, regional, and global levels;</li>
<li>develop the ability to communicate sophisticated ideas in a perceptive and effective manner across cultures;</li>
<li>understand the process involved in the design, development, and implementation of a research project as a leader of a team.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/film-and-screen-studies">Film and screen studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">ACX4050</span> - Issues in auditing and assurance<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ACX4050">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate, Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-accounting.html">Department of Accounting</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robyn Moroney">Professor Robyn Moroney</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACX4050&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ACX4050">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Students must be enrolled in course B3701 or B6002.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit considers both theoretical and professional issues relevant to the various participants to the audit process. The unit provides students with an overview of the nature of assurance and regulation of the audit profession, the economics of auditing, and the behavioural dimensions of auditing. Topics also include future directions for assurance services, fraud, internal control and corporate governance issues.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>evaluate and contrast research paradigms in auditing and assurance research</li>
<li>describe and evaluate the range of methods of decision making in auditing</li>
<li>critically evaluate empirical research and identify major research questions in auditing and assurance including audit quality, internal control, fraud and corporate governance</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills in individual and/or group activities dealing with issues in auditing and assurance and demonstrate in individual summative assessment tasks the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACX4050.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BMS2062</span> - Introduction to bioinformatics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BMS2062">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biomedical-sciences.html">School of Biomedical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Elizabeth Davis">Assoc. Professor Elizabeth Davis</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Anna Roujeinikova">Associate Professor Anna Roujeinikova</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Terry Kwok">Dr Terry Kwok</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMS2062&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BMS2062">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in one of the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science (including double degree programs)</li>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science (Scholar Program)</li>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science Advanced with Honours</li>
</ul>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>MOL2022.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Bioinformatics unites the major advances in biology, biochemistry and the biomedical sciences with those in computing, bioinformatics and networking. The unit covers the application of the internet to biomedical sciences; organisation and uses of scientific databases; use of computational methods in genomics and proteomics; fundamentals of molecular modelling; analysis and presentation of biomedical data; and communication of biomedical data using information technology.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse DNA and RNA sequences and predict gene products</li>
<li>Identify conserved features in sequences and structures that define the function of macromolecules</li>
<li>Navigate databases to identify sequences and data on mutations associated with disease.</li>
<li>Construct and analyse sequence alignments, molecular phylogeny and molecular models of proteins and design strategies to assess gene function by reverse genetics.</li>
<li>Interpret structural and functional effects of mutations and predict/state molecular mechanisms underlying the resulting disease.</li>
<li>Investigate and communicate, verbally and through writing, the applications of bioinformatics to areas of biomedical science including the development of drugs and therapeutics</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>In-semester theory tests (13%)</li>
<li>Final exam (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Projects and assignments (47%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle requirements: a pass grade in the final exam must be obtained to pass the unit. A pass in the projects and assignments must also be obtained to pass the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>2 Lectures per week, 1 three hour practical session per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/biomedical-science">Biomedical science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">ACW2851</span> - Accounting information systems and financial modelling<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ACW2851">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-accounting.html">Department of Accounting</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Siew Eu-Gene">Dr Siew Eu-Gene</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Siew Eu-Gene">Dr Siew Eu-Gene</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACW2851&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ACW2851&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ACW2851">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACW1100.html">ACW1100</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACC2400.html">ACC2400</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACF2400.html">ACF2400</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The objective of this unit is two-fold. First, the unit provides students with a broad introduction to accounting information systems and the role technology plays in accounting. The focus will be on an introduction to: enterprise systems; database management; documentation methods; internal controls; and the core business processes found in organisations. Second, the unit focuses on corporate modelling theory; models as decision support tools; types and uses of models; benefits and limitations of models; effective spreadsheet design; auditing spreadsheet models and development of various models using an industry standard spreadsheet.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>examine the role of accounting information systems in analysing and providing decision support to managers</li>
<li>explain the design of accounting information systems and financial models</li>
<li>develop financial models to assist in decision making</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and / or group activities dealing with accounting information systems and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACW2851.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 40% + Examination: 60%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">MEC4444</span> - Industrial noise and control<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MEC4444">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-mechanical-and-aerospace-engineering.html">Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Davies">Professor Chris Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Wing Kong Chiu">Professor Wing Kong Chiu</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Tan Ming Kwang">Dr Tan Ming Kwang</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MEC4444&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MEC4444">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MEC3453.html">MEC3453</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/TRC3200.html">TRC3200</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Fundamentals of sound and sound propagation, wave equation, Helmholtz equation, absorption, impedance and intensity, silencers. Transmission from one medium to another, applications and optimisation. Transmission through walls, mass law, coincidence and resonance. Sound transmission in the atmosphere, inverse square law, excess attenuation. Radiation of sound, directivity. Sound in enclosed spaces. Noise sources, noise reduction techniques, noise legislation and regulation, acceptable noise levels, hearing conservation, measurement and analysis of noise, design for low noise.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit, should are expected to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Calculate basic noise measurement quantities (sound pressure levels, sound power levels and sound intensity level);</li>
<li>Model the propagation of sound in a duct and in free-space;</li>
<li>Analyse the fundamentals of reactive noise attenuation devices;</li>
<li>Explain the concept of transmission loss:</li>
<li>Explain the concepts of direct and reverberant noise field in a close-environment;</li>
<li>Combine the concepts of noise source, noise path and noise measurement to examine the impact of a given noise source on its environment.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 40%</p>
<p>Final Examination (2 hours): 60%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>2 hours of lectures, 2 hours of laboratory/tutorial classes and 8 hours of private study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/mechanical-engineering">Mechanical Engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
