<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MKF3621</span> - Advertising management and campaigns<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MKF3621">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>

<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MKF3621">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKF3461.html">MKF3461</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Do you want to understand the strategic and creative thinking needed to develop successful advertising like the memorable 'Happy Little Vegemite' campaign and Metro's viral sensation, 'Dumb Ways to Die'? If so, this unit is for you! In Advertising Management and Campaigns, students will utilise concepts of synergy and integration to design and execute a real world strategic advertising campaign, putting theory into practice. Students also walk away with in-depth knowledge of the advertising industry and the relationships that exist within. With a priority on industry engagement, students will gain the skills and knowledge to confidently begin a career in the advertising industry.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning objectives of this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>investigate the importance of synergy and integration within the advertising industry, in particular, the process and relationships between the client and its various agencies</li>
<li>analyse the effectiveness of strategic advertising campaigns to determine industry best practice</li>
<li>design and execute a strategic advertising campaign, integrating market research, media planning, and creative resources based on a brief from industry</li>
<li>apply the pitch process to present a persuasive advertising campaign to a professional client</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">AZA3764</span> - Consulting<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-AZA3764">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-south-africa-school-of-social-science.html">South Africa School of Social Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Marianne Louw">Ms Marianne Louw</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Marianne Louw">Ms Marianne Louw</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=AZA3764&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-AZA3764">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-south-africa.html">South Africa</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS3764</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit explores consulting as a process by which an individual or firm assists a client to achieve a stated outcome in the complex South African markets of corporate communication and public relations. The unit considers a consultant as someone who has expertise in a specific area or areas and offers unbiased opinions and advice for a fee. The opinion or advice is rendered exclusively in the interests of the client. Activities and practices include the provision of information, assessment, analysis, recommendations and implementation strategies.</p>
<p>The scope of the unit is explicitly practical in its orientation.  It addresses the question: How can you turn your knowledge and abilities into a successful career outcome as a consultant in the communication industries?</p>
<p>The unit draws on the experience of selected individual professional consultants in South Africa. Students will be expected to formulate and (with assistance) work on their own consulting project. Related topics include client service, communication strategy, and proposals and presentations to clients.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>After successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>understand the consultant's role in the communication industry</li>
<li>describe the nature of a communication consultant's work</li>
<li>demonstrate problem-solving skills relevant to communication consulting</li>
<li>demonstrate presentation and reporting skills relevant to communication consulting.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/communication-and-media-studies---south-africa">Communication and media studies - South Africa</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/public-relations-practice---south-africa">Public relations practice - South Africa</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BMS2011</span> - Structure of the human body: An evolutionary and functional perspective<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BMS2011">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biomedical-sciences.html">School of Biomedical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Julia Choate">Dr Julia Choate</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Luca Fiorenza">Dr Luca Fiorenza</a>
<br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Kim Catania">Dr Kim Catania</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMS2011&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BMS2011">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in one of the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science (including double degree programs)</li>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science (Scholar Program)</li>
<li>Bachelor of Biomedical Science Advanced with Honours</li>
<li>Bachelor of Nutrition and Dietetics</li>
</ul>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ANT2331.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This course is an introduction to human anatomy. It includes an overview of  general principles of major body systems. This will be followed by a consideration of specific areas of regional anatomy from an evolutionary perspective. Namely, what distinguishes the human body from other primates, mammals and indeed vertebrates and how have these adaptations of anatomy contributed in a functional context to us being so successful.  Practical classes will involve exposure to human cadaver prosections, skeletal material, models and a range of imaging modalities including X-rays, CT scans etc.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe and contrast the structures and spatial relationships of the tissues, organs, systems, and regions that make up the human body.</li>
<li>Relate anatomical structures (tissues, organs, systems) to basic developmental processes and use comparative approaches to identify evolutionary and functional contexts.</li>
<li>Interpret and extrapolate sectional anatomical images to topographic anatomy using various methods and techniques such as medical imaging, measurement, drawing, and 3D printing</li>
<li>Integrate discrete anatomical knowledge into a comprehensive framework of body structures and systems</li>
<li>Work collaboratively to collect and analyse anatomical data.</li>
<li>Investigate and communicate, verbally and through writing, the developmental, evolutionary and functional aspects of human anatomy</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>In-semester test (1 hour) (25%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Practical Class Activities (25%)</li>
<li>Group Research project (10%)</li>
<li>End-of-semester exam (2 hours) (40%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>2 hours of lectures each week, 2 hours of practical content (face to face) each week and group project completion between Weeks 3-10. An additional 7 hours of private study is recommended per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/biomedical-science">Biomedical science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUR3002</span> - Integrated nursing practice 3<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUR3002">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-nursing-and-midwifery.html">School of Nursing and Midwifery</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Melanie Bishop">Melanie Bishop</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Melanie Bishop">Melanie Bishop</a>
        
        (Peninsula only)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUR3002&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUR3002">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>(NUR2002 or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR2106.html">NUR2106</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR2226.html">NUR2226</a></span>) and (NUR2004 or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR2206.html">NUR2206</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUR2228.html">NUR2228</a></span>) and (NUR2104 or NUR2107)</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in courses 3892, 4514</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This clinical practice unit provides an introduction to the management of clients with complex and or life threatening health problems across the lifespan with a particular focus on the acute care needs of the ageing individual. A case based approach will be utilized to facilitate the integration of advance health assessment skills, evidenced based practice and application of ethical principles in the management of complex nursing situations.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>demonstrate in-depth knowledge of a range of complex health problems experienced by clients throughout the lifespan;</li>
<li>describe the nursing application of diagnostic, therapeutic and preventative techniques associated with caring for a person with a complex body system health breakdown;</li>
<li>employ clinical and critical decision making skills to identify, analyse and resolve problems in the practice environment;</li>
<li>demonstrate the ability to apply time management and problem solving skills in the safe delivery of patient care;</li>
<li>evaluate the clinical application of evidence based research and the ethical principles in the safe management of complex health care issues;</li>
<li>develop and implement patient centred care interventions that encompass patient's complex health, cultural, ethical and developmental needs;</li>
<li>reflect critically on the role of the multidisciplinary team in provision of safe patient care;</li>
<li>practice with increasing independence in accordance with the Australian Nursing and Midwifery Council Competencies for Registered nurse, code of ethics and code of professional conduct for nurses.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Clinical Placement three (3) weeks (120 hours).</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Written assignment (2000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>Examination 2 hours (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
<li>Online case scenario (10%)</li>
<li>Clinical Placement: A -Performance Assessment: B - Placement Hours (20%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Workload requirements</p>
<ul>
<li>On campus learning (lectures, clinical learning environment and workshops): 32 hours</li>
<li>Guided work one (1) hour per week</li>
<li>Three (3) weeks of clinical placement at five (5) days/week (based on an 8 hour day/40 hour week, 120 hours in total).</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing">Nursing</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/nursing-and-midwifery">Nursing and midwifery</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

</ul>
</nav>
<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">MAE2405</span> - Aircraft performance<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MAE2405">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-mechanical-and-aerospace-engineering.html">Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Davies">Professor Chris Davies</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Hugh Blackburn">Professor Hugh Blackburn</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MAE2405&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MAE2405">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>24 Credit points</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>None</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>None</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The course provides an introduction to aircraft performance with the aim of enabling students to predict answers to questions such as: how high, how fast or how slowly can an aircraft fly, how quickly can it climb or turn in a circle, how much runway does it require to take off and land, and how much fuel does it need to travel a given distance.</p>
<p>The emphasis is on physical understanding, and the focus is on subsonic aircraft performance.  In order to support the aircraft performance topics that form the core of the course, basic fluid mechanics is introduced so that students can understand and predict the main sources of lift and drag forces produced on aircraft.</p>
<p>A brief introduction is also given to airbreathing aircraft powerplants so that students understand their basic characteristics and why different powerplant classes are appropriate to different flight speed regimes.  Aircraft longitudinal stability concepts are introduced, as are the basic phenomena of transonic and supersonic flight.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Calculate air properties at different altitudes according to the standard atmosphere model</li>
<li>Appreciate the application of concepts of conservation of mass, momentum and energy in fluid mechanics</li>
<li>Describe the central mechanisms of aircraft lift and drag production and using them to estimate boundary layer drag and lift-induced drag forces on aircraft</li>
<li>Distinguish why different powerplant classes are appropriate to different flight speed regimes, and how fuel use is characterised and to calculate aircraft range and endurance in powered and unpowered flight</li>
<li>For steady level flight be able to calculate how aircraft drag and drag power vary with flight speed and altitude, and able to calculate aircraft maximum and minimum speeds</li>
<li>Calculate speed and angle of climb in steady climbing flight</li>
<li>Calculate bank angle, turn speed and radius in steady horizontal turning flight at a given load factor</li>
<li>Calculate runway lengths required for takeoff and landing</li>
<li>Discuss the concepts of aircraft static longitudinal stability and neutral point</li>
<li>Explain the mechanisms of lift production in supersonic flight and how that differs from subsonic flight</li>
<li>Explain the reasoning underlying the introduction of wing sweep</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 40%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 60%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>3 hours lectures, 2 hours of practice classes and 7 hours of private study per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/aerospace-engineering">Aerospace Engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2066</span> - French proficient 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2066">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-french-studies.html">French Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Watkin">Dr Chris Watkin</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chris Watkin">Dr Chris Watkin</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2066&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2066">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2065.html">ATS2065</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS3066.html">ATS3066</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS2064.html">ATS2064</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>If this is your language entry point, this unit requires a <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/">language entry level test</a><span class="hbk-print-url">language entry level test (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/">http://www.monash.edu/arts/language-entry-level/</a>)</span>.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit develops language skills and cultural competence. The Language and Culture component of this unit aims to develop students' comprehension skills and capacity to express ideas in both oral and written French, through a range of class activities, both spoken and written. Students practise and develop their language skills in an area of French studies, developing competence in the theory, research methodology and practices, and discourses involved in critical enquiry, understanding and analysis in the discipline area.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Express themselves, both orally and in writing, correctly, fluently and appropriately, on a wide range of topics and in different contexts including situations in which instructions are given or requested, events are retold and chronological information provided, or refused, discourse is reported, described or commented upon, proposals are made and accepted or rejected, discourse has to be structured logically and hypotheses formulated, logical arguments are conveyed, accepted or refuted, information is processed, ideas presented or reported orally, and ideas are presented or reported in writing;</li>
<li>Understand and demonstrate understanding of written, audio and video documents;</li>
<li>Demonstrate explicit competence in French grammar in the areas reviewed;</li>
<li>Demonstrate competence in the use of language reference material;</li>
<li>Demonstrate autonomous learning strategies;</li>
<li>Demonstrate a greater critical knowledge and understanding of modern France and its culture;</li>
<li>Demonstrate competence in the theory, basic research methodology and practices, and discourses involved in critical enquiry, understanding and analysis in an area of French studies;</li>
<li>Demonstrate individual and cooperative research skills.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 85% + Exam: 15%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/french-studies">French studies</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">AMU3630</span> - Governing the global economy: Stability, efficiency, justice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-AMU3630">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-malaysia-school-of-arts-and-social-sciences.html">Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Marek Rutkowski">Dr Marek Rutkowski</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Marek Rutkowski">Dr Marek Rutkowski</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=AMU3630&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-AMU3630">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of second-year Arts units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS2630, ATS3630</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces students to the global economy and its governance. It enables students to critically examine conflicts among states, firms, international organizations, NGOs and other groups over how the global economy is governed. Key questions to be explored are:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>How do different political and economic ideas influence global economic governance, including in trade and finance, and whose interests are privileged as a result?</li>
<li>How have groups such as women and labour and issues such as the environment fared under neoliberal approaches to governance?</li>
<li>Should we govern the global economy to achieve stability and efficiency, or should we also attempt to achieve justice?</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify and interpret the changes that have occurred in how the world economy has been governed since the end of the Second World War;</li>
<li>Understand how different political and economic ideas that underpin distinct approaches to global economic governance privilege some actors and normative values at the expense of others;</li>
<li>Explain why conflicts occur among states, firms, international organizations, NGOs and other groups over how the global economy is governed;</li>
<li>Engage with and evaluate key normative debates on how the global economy should be governed.

<p>Students will meet the objectives of the unit by:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="A">
<li>Participating actively in tutorial discussions;</li>
<li>Reading critically about the topics covered in lectures;</li>
<li>Writing and submitting an essay that presents a well-researched and carefully argued analysis of the material covered in the unit;</li>
<li>Demonstrating in the examination knowledge and understanding of key concepts and theoretical debates on global economic governance and their application to different case studies.</li>
</ol></li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60%</p>
<p>Exam: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/global-studies">Global studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">IDE1802</span> - Materials and manufacturing 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-IDE1802">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Robbie Napper">Dr Robbie Napper</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=David Trickey">Mr David Trickey</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-IDE1802">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/DGN1001.html">DGN1001</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ARC2002.html">ARC2002</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>IDE2401</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The use of materials and manufacturing processes with particular reference to their application in product design. Product life cycle and environmental design considerations are taken into account to include disassembly techniques and the recycling of metals and plastics. Students gain an understanding of design applicable for low volume manufacture or batch production.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Have a basic knowledge of manufacturing methods;</li>
<li>Understand the properties of materials, used in manufacturing purposes;</li>
<li>Be able to interpret product designs for low volume, batch production;</li>
<li>Have a basic knowledge of applied mechanics relating to product design materials and structures;</li>
<li>Appreciate product life, recycling and environmental issues.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Class assignments (60%)</p>
<p>Examination (40%)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 3 hours of lectures and tutorials and 9 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BEX6300</span> - Philosophy of research<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">0 points, SCA Band 3, 0.000 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BEX6300">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Julie Wolfram Cox">Professor Julie Wolfram Cox</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Julie Wolfram Cox">Professor Julie Wolfram Cox</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BEX6300&amp;tpCode=T2-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 2</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BEX6300">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Term 2 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Term 2 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BEX6100.html">BEX6100</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BEX6200.html">BEX6200</a></span> and students must be enrolled in the 0029 Doctor of Philosophy or 3194 Master of Philosophy before undertaking this unit.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit discusses the fundamental epistemological premises on which HDR research may be developed. It explores ways of formulating research question(s) and hypotheses, and identifies assumptions and theories that are relevant in the development of a conceptual framework for research. The topics discussed will cover principles of the scientific method, key epistemological perspectives in the social sciences (e.g. positivism, interpretivism, social constructivism, hermeneutics, functionalism, critical theory) and argument analysis (e.g. avoiding fallacies in scientific reasoning, evaluating and constructing sound arguments). These discussions will clarify the theoretical and practical underpinnings of research design, inform subsequent analyses of how to select different research methods (qualitative, quantitative, mixed), and illustrate key issues associated with main argument development in a HDR thesis. Finally, the unit will examine ways of presenting a compelling theoretical and practical case for the epistemological significance of a HDR project, and examine how this approach could increase the likelihood of successful publication of research results.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>enhance awareness of the multiple epistemological and ontological perspectives that underpin research at HDR level</li>
<li>increase understanding of the principles involved in producing sound complex arguments as required in writing a HDR thesis</li>
<li>consider and evaluate research papers presented in the research seminar series</li>
<li>evaluate the literature, philosophical traditions, methods and problems associated with several topics</li>
<li>apply knowledge of ontological, epistemological, methodological and procedural assumptions to the preparation of papers that demonstrate an advanced understanding of the assumptions, methodology, techniques and results of research.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>36 hours per semester (split-block mode) of formal class contact.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">BMS4200</span> - Advanced studies in biomedical science<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 3, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BMS4200">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-biomedical-sciences.html">School of Biomedical Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Tim Cole">Associate Professor Tim Cole</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Tim Cole">Associate Professor Tim Cole</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMS4200&amp;tpCode=FY-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Full year</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BMS4200&amp;tpCode=S2-S1-02&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester to First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BMS4200">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Full year 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 to First semester 2020 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>A distinction level average in 24 points at third year level, including at least 12 points in 3rd year BMS units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BMS4100.html">BMS4100</a></span> and must be enrolled in course 3418.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit aims to develop analytical abilities and communication skills, as well as provide students with advanced knowledge in specific areas of Biomedical Science. Students will undertake a module of statistics relevant to scientific hypothesis testing and provide a written critique of a scientific article. Students will also undertake a component of work within their selected discipline that is unrelated to their specific research component and involves some level of advanced theoretical training. Candidates may commence at the beginning of either first or second semester.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Critically review the scientific literature in their discipline;</li>
<li>Explain the processes involved in the design, development and implementation of a research project;</li>
<li>Recognise the breadth of statistical tests and their applicability to common research methodologies;</li>
<li>Apply simple statistical tests.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Statistical test (30%)</li>
<li>Written critique (30%)</li>
<li>Discipline specific component (40%) (Hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/biomedical-science">Biomedical science</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="http://www.med.monash.edu.au/biomed/honours">http://www.med.monash.edu.au/biomed/honours</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">AHT3602</span> - Art criticism and curatorship<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-AHT3602">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-fine-art.html">Department of Fine Art</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<!-- TBA -->TBA
        
        
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Helen Hughes">Dr Helen Hughes</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-AHT3602">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>12 credit points at second year level in Art history and theory, or Theory of Art and Design, Visual Culture or permission from Unit Coordinator.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/AHT2602.html">AHT2602</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>, TAD2602, TAD3602, TAD3612</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>This unit was formerly coded TAD3602</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit explores the related practices of art criticism and curatorship and their role in communicating art to its publics. It offers a brief history of criticism/curatorship and critical/curatorial approaches, an assessment of reviews, including those of local exhibitions in Melbourne, and considerations of the theoretical underpinnings of critical reception. Students are invited to explore how they might themselves participate in the production of visual critique in the form of exhibition reviews, catalogue essays, curatorial statements, artist statements and so forth.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this subject students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Have a critical perspective of the selection of the voice, motives and bias of art critics and criticism;</li>
<li>Appreciate criticism as a genre of writing, with the unique cultural and practical contingencies acting upon it, and understand the variety of art writing which it comprises;</li>
<li>Understand the role of the curator as having a creative, political and active part in the production, mediation and dissemination of contemporary art;</li>
<li>Identify and understand the developments specific to the rise of curator as an important cultural commentator, and the contemporary challenges faced by art criticism;</li>
<li>Have developed their ability to think creatively and express their ideas clearly in written communication.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Assignment 1500 words (40%)</p>
<p>Research essay 2500 words (60%)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 3 contact hours and 9 hours independent study or equivalent.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">VCM4101</span> - Introduction to multimedia imaging<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-VCM4101">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-design.html">Department of Design</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jeffrey Janet">Mr Jeffrey Janet</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Samuel Berkoh">Mr Samuel Berkoh</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-VCM4101">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Admission to MMM &amp; MMDes course</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces the student to the different aspects of digital imaging for multimedia. The process of creating and using digital imaging effectively is defined and students will gain an understanding of the theory behind the inclusion of digital images in multimedia production. Students undertake project work which explores a range of technical skills and design concepts for incorporating digital images into multimedia production.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understand the process of converting visual material into a digital format using scanning and image capturing technology;</li>
<li>Understand the types of digital imaging including still graphics, animation and video, 2D and 3D;</li>
<li>Understand the composition of the digital image including resolution and compression formats;</li>
<li>Have the skills to manipulate digital images using digital editing software;</li>
<li>Have the skills to create a digital image using digital editing software;</li>
<li>Be aware of the different digital image formats applicable to different multimedia authoring environments;</li>
<li>Understand the process of inclusion of digital images into multimedia authoring environments.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Individual projects (75%)</p>
<p>Essay 1250 words (25%)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including a 1-hour lecture, 2 studio hours and 9 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2508</span> - Introduction to poetry writing<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2508">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-literary-studies.html">Literary Studies</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=John Hawke">Dr John Hawke</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=John Hawke">Dr John Hawke</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2508&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2508">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Two gateway units in Literary studies, or permission from the unit coordinator.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS3508</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The subject examines the tradition of modern poetry and poetics and its applicability to contemporary writing practice from a comparative approach. The subject concentrates on a number of key texts from the Symbolist and Modernist periods and examines various works which may be seen to exemplify, modify, or challenge these poetics. Students will be required to reflect both creatively and analytically on their own writing practice in the light of these texts. In the collaborative environment of workshops, students will be encouraged to experiment with a range of Modernist techniques including: free verse, parataxis, the ideogramic method, automatic writing, visual and sound poetry.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The proposed subject aims to introduce students to a range of primary texts within the field of modern poetry and poetics, providing the opportunity to develop critical and creative skills. At the successful completion of this subject the student will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Articulate the key features of major developments in modern poetics</li>
<li>Reflect critically on his/her writing practice in the light of these developments</li>
<li>Demonstrate how a given text exemplifies or challenges contemporaneous theories of poetics</li>
<li>Devise writing strategies which utilise in direct or modified ways (oppositional or ironic) aspects of a given poetics within their writing practice</li>
<li>Demonstrate critical skills through the editorial commentary on works in progress presented in workshops</li>
<li>Develop creative and professional skills through the drafting process.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/literary-studies">Literary studies</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

</div>
<div id="content_container_">

<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ACC3200">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>

<br/>

</li>
<li>

</li>

</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ACC3200">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>

</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">

<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>

</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit focuses on the provision and use of management accounting information for management planning and control in organisations. Technical and behavioural issues related to budgeting, variance analysis, performance measurement, and value chain management are considered.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>apply management accounting techniques to enable managers to measure and enhance organisational performance</li>
<li>analyse and make recommendations regarding the design of management accounting systems</li>
<li>critically evaluate management accounting systems in terms of their behavioural implications</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, problem solving and communication skills to indivudual and/or group activities to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered in the unit.</li>
<li>enhance your ability to work effectively in a group.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">EAE2122</span> - Introduction to atmospheric physics and dynamics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-EAE2122">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-earth-atmosphere-and-environment.html">School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Martin Singh">Dr Martin Singh</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Martin Singh">Dr Martin Singh</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=EAE2122&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-EAE2122">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>One of <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/EAE2011.html">EAE2011</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MTH1030.html">MTH1030</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MTH1035.html">MTH1035</a></span> OR <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ENG1005.html">ENG1005</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATM2030</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit examines atmospheric thermodynamics and dynamics, including cloud processes, the dynamics and prediction of severe storms (including tornadoes and tropical cyclones), the structure and evolution of extra-tropical cyclones and their associated fronts, and the techniques used in forecasting the day-to-day weather.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe the basic thermodynamics of the atmosphere and the forces acting upon it, and explain how these forces lead to atmospheric motions;</li>
<li>Identify and describe the main processes leading to the formation of clouds;</li>
<li>Distinguish and classify different cloud types;</li>
<li>Apply conceptual knowledge of the atmosphere to real-life weather systems, including severe storms, tornadoes and tropical cyclones, and use appropriate techniques for forecasting day-to-day weather;</li>
<li>Integrate key concepts of atmospheric physics and dynamics to analyse and solve quantitative meteorological problems</li>
<li>Interpret quantitative meteorological information using appropriate mathematical, statistical, and graphical tools.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Assignments and practicals: 30%</p>
<p>Tests: 20%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Three hours of lectures</li>
<li>One 2-hour tutorial per week</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/atmospheric-science">Atmospheric science</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/earth-science">Earth science</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">RAD2007</span> - Medical radiation science: Professional skills 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-RAD2007">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-medical-imaging-and-radiation-sciences.html">Department of Medical Imaging and Radiation Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Lori Boyd">Ms Lori Boyd</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Lori Boyd">Ms Lori Boyd</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Quota applies</p>
<p>This unit is quota restricted. Selection is on a first-in, first enrolled basis. 
      
      
      </p><p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=RAD2007&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-RAD2007">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RAD2005.html">RAD2005</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Units: <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RAD2006.html">RAD2006</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RAD2001.html">RAD2001</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RAD2003.html">RAD2003</a></span></p>
<p>Course: M2013 or M20024</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is the second of two units that teach concepts related to professional practice and patient care in the radiation sciences professions.</p>
<p>Students will critically analyse the concept of professional regulation and they will explore codes of conduct and professional guidelines health professionals.</p>
<p>This unit will also include an introduction to legal and ethical aspects related to working in the health professions, with a focus on medical radiations practice.</p>
<p>Communication and reflective practice will be explored and students will develop these skills and apply them in a simulated environment.</p>
<p>Occupational health and safety, manual handling and infection control will also be covered together with application of the skills in a simulated environment.</p>
<p>Students will build on their previously developed cultural competence and understanding of inter-professional practice with a focus on managing patients with different needs.</p>
<p>Students will undertake a clinical orientation in a radiation therapy centre during the semester.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Explain the legal and ethical concepts related to health care practice, including professional regulation of medical radiation practitioners</li>
<li>Describe occupational health and safety (and radiation safety) considerations in the context of the medical radiation practice professions and clinical environment</li>
<li>Describe and apply communication theory, cultural competence and reflective practice theory</li>
<li>Evaluate the challenges associated with managing patients with a range of different needs including the elderly, children, patients with physical disability or mental impairment.</li>
<li>Analyse and reflect on inter-professional practice in the context of the medical radiation practice professions</li>
<li>Demonstrate the key concepts of professional practice to a beginner level during clinical orientation placement</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>2 days of clinical placement</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Clinical workbook and activities (2,000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>iSAP case (2,000 words) (30%)</li>
<li>End of semester exam (2 hours) (40%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle requirements</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>80% attendance at tutorials to foster a professional approach to attendance and to facilitate group work.</li>
<li>100% attendance at the two day clinical orientation and successful completion of clinical orientation workbook and portfolio on pebble pad.</li>
<li>Students must pass each element of assessment to pass the unit, which means that students will have to put the same amount of effort into all assessments elements.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>1 hour lecture, and a 2 hour tutorial per week, 9 hours of self-directed interaction with Moodle based tasks, readings and activities per week and online support sessions.</p>
<p>2 Day clinical orientation to a radiation therapy centre</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/radiography-and-medical-imaging">Radiography and medical imaging</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/radiation-sciences">Radiation sciences</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">CHM4211</span> - Chemistry honours coursework part-time A<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CHM4211">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-chemistry.html">School of Chemistry</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Michael Grace">Assoc Professor Michael Grace</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Michael Grace">Assoc Professor Michael Grace</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CHM4211&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CHM4211">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Enrolment in an approved Honours or Graduate Diploma in the discipline of chemistry</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>All students will undertake a Professional Studies topic and one core topic defined by the School, as well as three elective topics from specialised areas of chemistry, such as pericyclic reactions, separation science, advanced organic synthesis, main group inorganic chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, computational chemistry and electron microscopy. Each topic will require students to attend 8 lecture equivalents making a total of 48 lecture equivalents for the unit. Further information is available from the course coordinator and at a meeting held with prospective students during second semester of third year.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Combination of examination and/or assignment (depending on the topic): 100% + Please consult the course coordinator about the assessment of individual topics.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/chemistry">Chemistry</a></p>
</div>
